DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Sweeping Democratic Reforms; Restores Historic Name
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Saturday approved sweeping democratic reforms that for the first time in 45 years allow the formation of new political parties, protect private property and scrap the Communists' guaranteed leading role in society. Lawmakers also restored Poland's historic name and national emblem, both changed after the Soviet-backed Communists took power in 1944. In an emotional end to the session's work, members rose and sang the national anthem and ``God Who Watches Over Poland.'' The two houses of Parliament had met in almost constant session over the past four days, passing the most radical economic reforms ever attempted in the East bloc and creating a more democratic constitution. ``I am optimistic,'' Solidarity Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki told reporters during a reception in Parliament when asked what he thought the coming year would bring. The constitutional amendments give citizens the right to create independent political parties. Until now, the Communist Party, the Democratic Party and the Peasant Party were the only legally recognized parties in Poland. Solidarity, which began as a labor union, has become a de facto political party. The amended constitution also guarantees the protection of private property, much of which was seized by the Communists at the end of World War II. The Senate approved the changes on a 79-0 vote with two abstentions. The Sejm, as the lower house of Parliament is called, adopted the amendments 374-1 with 11 abstentions late Friday, but Senate approval of Sejm votes is required for bills to become law. The amendments drop or modify articles in the constitution inconsistent with democratic reforms introduced since Solidarity scored a stunning victory in June elections that led to formation of the East bloc's first non-Communist government. The amendments restored the Republic of Poland as the country's official name from the People's Republic of Poland, which was imposed by the Communists four decades ago. A smiling announcer on the late afternoon news program TeleExpress greeted viewers in the ``Republic of Poland.'' Following similar action in other formerly rigid Communist countries in Eastern Europe, the Parliament deleted a constitutional clause that guaranteed the leading role of the Communist Party in society. The amendments also restored democratic language and traditions, changing a phrase that called Poland a ``socialist society'' to a ``citizens' society.'' In addition, the pre-war crown that graced the head of the eagle on the national emblem was restored. The crown symbolizes Polish sovereignty and unity. After the Senate vote, an eagle with a crown, brought two weeks earlier by a farmer, was hung in the Senate hall. The farmer, whose name was not noted when he made the gift to the Senate's Human Rights Commission, said the eagle was the only souvenir he had of his father. In addition to their legislative sessions, Poland's political leaders, who less than a year ago were at odds with each other, met to exchange greetings for the New Year. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa met Saturday with Communist Party leader Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski. Mazowiecki met with Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski on Friday after Cardinal Jozef Glemp made the first postwar visit by a Polish primate to Parliament. On Friday, the Senate approved a package of 11 economic laws backed by the Solidarity-led government to create a market-oriented economy and reduce inflation. If successful, the economic package, which covers credit policy, joint ventures, foreign capital, hard currency, customs and taxation, will transform economic life in Poland. Two laws on unemployment are designed to protect the 400,000 workers the government estimates could lose their jobs as Poland makes the difficult transition to a market economy. The plan is likely to result in the closing of some inefficient enterprises. Other laws regulate financing of state enterprises and limit the growth of wages, a measure designed to hold down inflation now running at 900 percent.
